Award.AbstractNarration:
Suppose one day all workers in the U.S. were randomly reallocated across all existing jobs. Would there be any effect on output? It seems likely that the answer is ``yes''. This suggests that aggregate output and productivity depend on the actual allocation of individual workers to particular jobs. This project extends the state-of-the-art theory of sorting of workers across jobs to include the ability of workers to search for better jobs while employed. It then shows that, using only routinely available matched employer-employee data on wages and labor market transition rates, it is possible to recover the output of any observed employer-employee match and the consequences for output, productivity, and wages of moving any worker to any firm in the economy. The proposed model and measurement method will be used to provide substantive empirical answers to a number of classic but yet unanswered economic questions.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in the following. (1) The PI develops an assortative matching model with on-the-job search and proves its nonparametric identification. (2) The PI draws on the recent advances in computer science to develop algorithms to implement the proposed identification strategy in practice given the potential limitations of existent data sets. (3) The PI will provide the theoretical methodology for answering important empirical questions in the context of an equilibrium model. (4) The PI will provide substantive answers to these questions.

The project will have a broad impact. (1) It will provide a new model and empirical methodology for studying sorting in the labor market. (2) It will develop and and make publicly available the computational tools that enable this study. (3) New empirical findings obtained using these tools will provide a better understanding of fundamental economic issues and have a potential to substantially impact the design and evaluation of existing public policies. Fundamentally, the PI shows how the US government, using the data it already has access to, can to overcome frictions in the labor market and improve allocation of workers to jobs. This may eventually result in a substantial improvement in economic competitiveness of the United States. The results will also inform optimal design of policies, such as unemployment insurance. (4) It will provide training to graduate and postgraduate students in the development and applications of these tools and methods. (5) The results of this research will be presented at prominent national and international academic and policy conferences and seminars. They are also likely to become a standard entry on the reading lists in advanced courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Suppose one day all workers in the U.S. were randomly reallocated across all existing jobs. Would there be any effect on output? It seems likely that the answer is ``yes''. As worker and firm attributes observable in the data account for only some 30% of the variation in wages, the answer will likely remain ``yes'' even if we condition the experiment on all such characteristics. This is indicative of complementarities between workers and jobs and of sorting of workers across jobs based on these unobserved (to the economist) characteristics.

From the perspective of economic theory, a typical starting point for thinking about assignment problems in heterogeneous agent economies in presence of such complementarities is the model of Becker (1973) extended to allow for time consuming search between workers and firms in Shimer and Smith (2000). However, the empirical usefulness of that framework is limited by the fact that it does not include on-the-job search, which is a key feature of the data.

The major objective of this research was to overcome this limitation. Specifically, my collaborators and I have developed a novel empirically-relevant but tractable assignment model with on-the-job search; proved its theoretical identification; developed a scalable algorithm that implements the theoretical identification strategy for the proposed model; performed a Monte Carlo study which revealed that the proposed identification strategy and the implementation method are successful at measuring the relevant objects in the model. Finally, we implemented these methods in the data and obtained several key insights:

(a)    There is a high degree of sorting with a rank correlation of 0.75 between workers and firms, implying the overall tendency for more productive workers to work at the more productive firms.

 

(b)    Firms matching with more productive workers also have a much higher value of the vacancy, indicating that firms cannot scale up production arbitrarily and drive the value of the vacancy down to zero at the firm level as is commonly assumed.

 

(c)     While overall more productive workers tend to work in more productive firms, locally, the patterns of sorting are more complicated. In contrast to the standard assumptions on the production function, its cross-partial derivative does not have a constant sign.

 

(d)    This curvature of the production function is relatively well exploited by market participants: the solution to the optimal output maximizing assignment problem implies that it increases output by only 1.83%.

 

(e)    Reassigning workers to the main diagonal (i.e., best worker to the best job, second best worker to the second best job, all the way down the ranks), as would be optimal under the standard assumption on the production function leads to a decline in output. This highlights the importance of a non-parametric recovery of the production function, which is the focus of this research project.

 

Another objective of this research was to assess the effects of policies, such as the duration or generosity of unemployment insurance benefits, which may facilitating better matching of workers to firms but at a potential cost of discouraging job creation and job search effort. Until this research, the literature has focused on studying the effects of these policies on individual job search effort. This provides only an incomplete picture. The key insight of several papers produced as part of this research is that the impact of these policies on job creation is economically very important. Moreover, to fully measure this effect, one also has to evaluate the impact of policies on aggregate demand. Existing research was largely limited to models without worker and firm heterogeneity and featured indeterminate price levels for at least some monetary policies of practical interest and thus could not pin down the size of the effect on aggregate demand. The research supported by this award overcomes these limitations.

 

While the impact of economic policies on worker sorting across jobs and the dynamics of their incomes is of independent interest, ultimately, the crucial question for policy evaluation is how these policies affect consumption. The only dataset that contains longitudinal earnings, income and consumption data for a representative sample of U.S. household is the Panel Study of Income Dynamics.  When laying the foundation for the study of the welfare effects of labor market sorting and economic policies, this research has identified an unexpected pattern in these data which might present a major concern regarding sampling, interviewing, or data processing methodology. Given the absolutely central role of this dataset in the research in many social sciences, understanding this is an issue of first order importance and might call for a fundamental reassessment of a large body of knowledge.

 

Numerous students participated in this research. Its findings were presented at prominent national and international academic and policy conferences and seminars. They are also becoming a standard entry on the reading lists in advanced courses.
